title: WSL: MCP server is not installed in the right place
body:
Testing #258369 Type: Bug I had a MCP server installed in my host machine, but when trying to use it via WSL it fails to launch. I use `fnm` to for setup node versions as need. In this case, `npx` was available in WSL, but the server was not using it. We need a way to get the host config to work in WSL similar to how we handle extensions for remotes. repro steps: install context7 mcp server on host start a WSL session, with `fnm use 22` followed by `code-insiders .` Try starting the context7 server. ``` 2025-07-29 08:51:26.261 [info] Starting server from LocalProcess extension host 2025-07-29 08:51:26.280 [debug] Server command line: npx -y @upstash/context7-mcp@latest 2025-07-29 08:51:26.284 [info] Connection state: Starting 2025-07-29 08:51:26.290 [info] Connection state: Error spawn npx ENOENT ``` VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.103.0-insider (4968600c8228730f6256de900c42900297e90b46, 2025-07-29T05:08:02.836Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 5.15.146.1-microsoft-standard-WSL2

title: Better UX for workspace vs user mcp config

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Testing #258363

Couldn't find an easy way to install mcp servers in the workspace mcp configuration.
1. Go to the workspace mcp.json file
2. Click `Add Server...`
3. `Browse MCP Servers...`
4. Click on `Browse MCP Servers` (would be nice if we avoid this second click)
5. Install any MCP server
6. Notice that it gets installed into the user settings

Ended up needing to copy paste the config into the workspace one

title: Just kept repeating the same string over and over.
body:
Type: Bug I gave it this prompt in Ask mode: Create a new schema called LangLocale. The fields on it should be id, lang (defined by an enum called LangCodes that has names of languages for about 100 of the largest langauges (the names of the languages should be in the language itself (language names should not all be in English; the only langauge name that should be in English is "English")); these language names should only be capitalized if they are capitalized by norm in the language itself (for example, English, español, português, Deutsch, etc.)), locale (defined by an enum called LocaleCodes that has names of all the countries in the world (United States, France, Canada, Guatemala, etc.). It should also include the region "Latin America"). It started off well, giving me ```enum LangCodes { English español português Deutsch français italiano русский 中文 日本語 한국어 العربية हिन्दी বাংলা اردو Türkçe فارسی Ελληνικά Nederlands svenska dansk norsk suomi polski čeština magyar română українська српски hrvatski bosanski slovenský slovenščina lietuvių latviešu eesti ქართული հայերեն עברית ไทย Việt BahasaIndonesia Melayu Filipino isiZulu Afrikaans Kiswahili Somali Malagasy Shqip Македонски беларуская ქართული```, but then it just kept repeating `ქართული` over and over. title: Copilot pro not allowing premium requests (rate limit hit)
body:
Type: Bug I am experiencing a critical issue with GitHub Copilot Premium requests in VS Code. Despite having an active Copilot Pro subscription and increasing my 'Copilot Premium Request' budget to $10 (with 'Stop usage when budget limit is reached' unchecked), I am consistently being blocked from using premium models after the very first request per VS Code launch Specific Behavior: Upon launching VS Code and making the first premium request (e.g., to Sonnet in Copilot Chat), it works successfully. Any subsequent premium request immediately fails with the message: "You have exceeded your premium request allowance." My premium requests usage often shows 100%+ in the Copilot status bar, even though I have available budget and am actively being charged for any successful premium requests. Troubleshooting Steps Already Performed: Confirmed active Copilot Pro subscription and correct budget/settings on GitHub billing page. Signed out and signed back into GitHub account in VS Code. Uninstalled and reinstalled the GitHub Copilot extension. Ensured VS Code and Copilot extension are on the latest versions. Tested on different networks ) and confirmed no firewall/proxy issues (as the first request works). Start speaking to your microphone Expected behavior: "I'm listening..." placeholder message changes to speech-to-text output while speaking into the microphone. title: Extreme lag after updating to v1.102.2.

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

body:
Type: Performance Issue I thought it might be an extension causing it, at first, but the issue persists even in a different profile with no community extensions running. It started happening right after updating. Symptoms include the following: - Tooltips for source code files failing to load (they endlessly say "Loading..."). - Drag-and-Drop files taking 2+ minutes to complete, with notification stating something about "participants". - Setting changes, either with the GUI or config file, don't take effect for up to 10 sec. - Miscellaneous other "lag-related" issues. <!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Feature Request: Option to hide/minimize "files changed" section in Copilot chat

Description: The "files changed" section that appears above the chat input takes up valuable screen space. It would be helpful to have an option to:
- Collapse/minimize this section with a toggle button
- Hide it completely via settings
- Auto-collapse it after a certain number of files

This would improve the chat experience, especially on smaller screens or when working with many file changes.

title: Disable "formatting-only" suggestions in Next Edit Suggestion

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: verification-needed
labels.description: Verification of issue is requested

labels.name: NES
labels.description: Issues related to the next edit suggestions feature

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Developers are used to tools which auto-format their code for them (Prettier, format on save, etc). When working with Next Edit Suggestions, the suggestion frequently is to simply format the recently modified code. This is distracting and slows down development, as it takes time to process what the suggestion is. It does not matter whether I accept or ignore the suggestion, as the code will be formatted automatically by other tools, and so it wastes time and slows down actual development.

I'd like to suggest a setting to disable formatting-only modifications from Next Edit Suggestions. Alternatively, we could use custom instructions specifically for Next Edit Suggestions to request no formatting-only modifications.

title: Fix secret key enumeration error by handling non-JSON keys gracefully
body:
The secret key enumeration feature was failing with a JSON parsing error when VS Code core stored non-JSON keys alongside extension keys in the secret storage.

**Issue**: When extensions called `secretStorage.keys()` to enumerate their stored secrets, the operation would crash with:
```
SyntaxError: Unexpected token 'm', "mcpEncryptionKey" is not valid JSON
```

**Root Cause**: The `doGetKeys` method in `MainThreadSecretState` assumed all secret storage keys were JSON-formatted extension keys like `{"extensionId": "extension.id", "key": "userKey"}`. However, VS Code core also stores secrets with plain string keys like `"mcpEncryptionKey"`, causing `JSON.parse()` to fail.

**Solution**: Added a try-catch block around the `parseKey(key)` call to gracefully handle non-JSON keys. The fix follows the existing pattern already used in the `onDidChangeSecret` handler in the same file:

```typescript
.map(key => {
    try {
        return this.parseKey(key);
    } catch (e) {
        // Core can use non-JSON values as keys, so we may not be able to parse them.
        return null;
    }
})
.filter(parsed => parsed !== null && parsed.extensionId === extensionId)
```

This ensures that:
- Extension keys are correctly parsed and returned for the requesting extension
- Non-JSON keys are silently ignored without causing crashes
- The API remains backward compatible

**Testing**: Added comprehensive tests covering the error scenario and edge cases including empty arrays, malformed JSON, and mixed key types.

Fixes #258383.

title: Shell integration not working correctly for `Pseudoterminal`
body:
My extension implements a `Pseudoterminal` that accepts multi-line input. When the user presses `Enter` to start mutli-line mode, all extra lines are prefixed with `... ` (like the Node REPL) to show the user that the text is part of the command input. Here's an example of what this looks like in the UI:

```
Connected to localhost:52773/iris as _SYSTEM

USER>d {
... w $zv
... } while 0
IRIS for UNIX (Apple macOS for Apple Silicon) 2025.3.0L (Build 142U) Mon Jul 14 2025 21:57:15 EDT
USER>
```

When the multi-line input is finally sent for execution, we send the following shell integration escape sequences:

```
\x1b]633;E;${this._inputEscaped()}\x07\x1b]633;C\x07\r\n
```

where `this_inputEscaped()` resolves to `d\x20{\x0d\x0aw\x20$zv\x0d\x0a}\x20while\x200` for the example above. Note that there are no leading dots on the additional lines. However, in the handler for the `onDidStartTerminalShellExecution` event, the `execution.commandLine.value` is:

```
d {
... w $zv
... } while 0
```

The `execution.commandLine.confidence` is `2`, so my shell integration is working properly. Is this a bug in VS Code or my extension?

- VS Code Version: 1.102.2

title: Only change the line height of the view line
body: Previously, if a decoration specified a custom line height, this affected all viewlines that are covered by model line. Now the line height is only applied to the view lines that render the decoration. It is still possible to change the line height of an entire view line by setting the decoration option `isWholeLine`. Closes #249967 cc @aiday-mar

title: Fix duplicate Windows 11 context menu entries for VS Code Insiders
body:
This PR fixes an issue where VS Code Insiders users on Windows 11 were seeing duplicate "Open with Code Insiders" entries in the modern context menu after updating their installation.

## Problem

The issue occurred when users upgraded from VS Code Insiders versions that used the old context menu DLL naming (`code_explorer_command_*.dll`) to newer versions that use the updated naming (`code_insider_explorer_command_*.dll`). During this transition, the old AppX package registrations weren't being cleaned up, causing both the old and new context menu registrations to remain active.

This resulted in duplicate entries appearing in Windows 11's modern context menu, as shown in the issue screenshots, while the classic context menu correctly showed only one entry.

## Root Cause

The problem was introduced when VS Code Insiders changed its AppX package naming scheme:
- **Before**: Used `code_*.appx` with `code_explorer_command_*.dll` (same as stable)  
- **After**: Uses `code_insider_*.appx` with `code_insider_explorer_command_*.dll` (unique for insiders)

When upgrading, the installer didn't remove the old AppX package registration, leaving both packages registered and causing duplicate context menu entries.

## Solution

Added targeted cleanup logic in the Inno Setup installer (`build/win32/code.iss`) that:

1. **Scope-limited**: Only runs for insider quality builds on Windows 11 or later
2. **Conditional**: Only executes when the context menu integration option is selected
3. **Safe removal**: Uses PowerShell to identify and remove old VS Code AppX packages that match the pre-rename naming pattern
4. **Error-tolerant**: Includes comprehensive exception handling to ensure installation continues even if cleanup fails
5. **Precise targeting**: Uses specific pattern matching to avoid affecting stable VS Code installations

The cleanup specifically targets AppX packages matching `Microsoft.VSCode` with the old `code_*.appx` pattern while excluding packages containing `code_insider`, ensuring only the problematic old registrations are removed.

Fixes #258418.

title: Checkpoint - Undo Last Request/Redo Last Request
body:
Testing #258351

1. Send a message 
2. After the turn is completed use the "Undo Last Request" action

My expectation was that this should be equivalent with "Restore Checkpoint" but that was not the case. It seems like a turn can contain multiple requests and that is what the Undo/Redo Last Requests actions are doing. Is that the case? I believe that the unit that is "undone" should always be a turn and not a subset of the turn.
